definition: gossip/hearsay/rumor

road/path/CL:條|条[tiao2],股[gu3]/principle/truth/morality/reason/skill/method/Dao (of Daoism)/to say/to speak/to talk/classifier for long thin things (rivers, cracks etc), barriers (walls, doors etc), questions (in an exam etc), commands, courses in a meal, steps in a process/(old) circuit (administrative division)
to listen/to hear/to obey/a can (loanword from English "tin")/classifier for canned beverages
smile (archaic)
(literary pronunciation, still advocated in Taiwan) to rule/to sentence/to allow
way/route/road
to persuade
to speak/to say/to explain/to scold/to tell off/a theory (typically the last character in a compound, as in 日心說|日心说 heliocentric theory)
variant of 說|说[shuo1]

sentences.english: Will also descend the tunnel sees, always listen to than other people panic nervous Zhang Dao the way say well.
sentences.chinese: 也会下隧道去看，总比别人慌慌张张道听途说的好。

sentences.english: Even just passing gossip and hearsay can prime your mind for illness with potent effect.
sentences.chinese: 哪怕只传传流言蜚语和道听途说都能灌输强烈影响。

sentences.english: Nevertheless, you are OK also these message regard as bru it or it is gossip.
sentences.chinese: 不过，你也可以将这些消息看做谣传或是道听途说。

sentences.english: They're just going by hearsay and duplicating what they think the pro's are using.
sentences.chinese: 他们只是去的道听途说和重复表里如一亲的使用。

sentences.english: The attorney for the defense challenged the evidence as hearsay.
sentences.chinese: 被告辩护律师驳斥该证据为道听途说。

sentences.english: You must have heard it through the grapevine.
It's nothing more than to defend the historical memory.
sentences.chinese: 太史公道听途说，无非是为了捍卫历史的记忆。

sentences.english: Believe not whatever you see nor half what you hear.
sentences.chinese: 虽眼见亦不能全信，道听途说更不足信。

sentences.english: Gossip is what no one claims to like, but everybody enjoys.
sentences.chinese: 没有人自称喜欢道听途说，但人人都乐此不倦。

definition: to spread falsehoods/to increasingly distort the truth/to pile errors on top of errors (idiom)
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
to assume/assumption
to concoct a cock-and-bull story (idiom)/to make things up
fabrication relying on nothing (idiom); frame-up
selective listening/to hear what one wants to hear
rumor
assumption/guess
one side of the story/one-sided statement
to fabricate/to make sth up/invented
hearsay/gossip
random lies and falsehoods
to make far-fetched claims (idiom)/to offer outlandish explanations
to jump to an unfounded conclusion
lit. to believe in the rain on hearing the wind (idiom)/to believe rumors/to be credulous
to make things up/to concoct (a story, an excuse etc)
